Dear ELEANOR LOUISE MARQUIS:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
2/24/2025-2/28/2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written
corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date
of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
• (4) An agency shall document placement
specifications consistent with the information
contained in the reevaluation. The placement
specifications must include all the following:
• (a) The age, number, SOGIE, race, ethnic
background, and characteristics of children
preferred by the applicants.
5 of 6 open foster home files reviewed contained reevaluation reports with
placement specification that did not include the SOGIE preferred by the applicant.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
• (8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and
make a licensing recommendation to the
department at least 15 calendar days before the
expiration date of the foster home license.
1 of 6 open foster home files reviewed contained a reevaluation that was not
completed and submitted to the department with a recommendation at least 15 days
before the expiration date of the license.
2

• (2) An agency shall give a copy of the program
statement to a youth before placement in
independent living.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Interim reevaluations must be completed at least 15 days prior to the
interim licensing date (ex. license exp 6/11/24, every reevaluation must be
completed by 5/28 at the latest).
• When asking foster parents about their willingness to accept a youth's
SOGIE, be sure to ask specifics regarding sexual orientation, gender
identity, and expression.
• If given permission by someone to indicate their agreement on a physical
form, be sure to clearly state why a physical signature could not be
obtained and that the person consented to agree to the document.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Quality contacts: One record contained case contacts that had very
minimal content for face-to-face visits with the youth in the youth's
placement.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incident of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were 2 incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. Both Special evaluation reports were completed thoroughly and included
appropriate recommendations and CAPs based on the incidents and findings.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
5

The one CAP submitted during the period under review was submitted in response
to the 2024 renewal inspection report dated 3/7/2024 and was approved on
3/27/2024. That CAP addressed 12 violations, two of which were policy violations
(PATP signatures & and FTMs) and one of which was a PA 116 violation
(Confidentiality). Of the remaining nine violations, the agency has achieved and
maintained compliance. The one violation repeated this year was related to face-
to-face visits with Independent Living youth is the youth's place of residence. The
violation was also present during the 2023 inspection and will require analysis as
to why prior CAPs were not effective.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator report was completed on 2/24/25 and identified areas in
which the agency had barriers to maintaining compliance. The first was
medical/dental exams and the barriers identified were caregiver failure to
communicate the need to change appointments, lack of local providers, limited
regional options, and older youth refusal. Barriers to maintaining placements for
youth with challenging behaviors were lack of local mental health providers, lack of
providers familiar with trauma-based therapy models, lack of respite providers,
older youths' unwillingness to comply with services, and limited number of homes
willing to accept older youths. Barriers to parental involvement included limited
public transportation options, high percentage of substance abuse, lack of access
to affordable and stable housing, criminal activity, and mental health concerns.
Barriers to sibling visits included distance between placements, and schedule
coordination for large sibling groups. Additionally, three workers left during the
period under review. The Quality Assurance Analyst position was also vacant for a
period of time during the period under review which led to a decline in tracking and
auditing until that position was filled. The agency has hired two new workers and a
social service aide. There has been an increase in compliance with worker-child
visits, worker parent visits, and service plan timeliness
Financial Overview
N/A
Staff and Youth Interviews
The staff members interviewed reported receiving supportive supervision
throughout the year during which some workers left the agency and some were on
medical or parental leave. They reported utilizing tracking methods implemented
after previous inspection CAPs which have been helpful maintaining compliance.
No concerns were reported.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The office appeared to have adequate space and equipment to provide for the
delivery of foster home certification, foster care, and independent living services.
Files are stored in a secured file area with locked cabinets containing closed
adoption files.
6

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
No safety concerns identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
